LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communications 
Subsector: Railways 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth 
Subthemes: Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, and 
fostering physical infrastructure development 
   
Environment  Category A. An environmental impact assessment was completed and 
Assessment  the summary was circulated to the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) 
Board of Directors on 4 January 2008. 
   
Project Description  The  Chongqing–Lichuan  Railway  (CLR)  Development  Project  is  a 
priority project included in the Eleventh Five-Year Plan (11FYP) of the 
Government of the PRC (Government). The Project is located in the 
central  part  of  Chongqing  municipality  and  the  northwestern  part  of 
Hubei  province,  a  relatively  poor  area,  and  is  designed  to  promote 
sustainable economic growth by constructing 259 kilometers (km) of 
railway line from Chongqing to Lichuan in Hubei province. The Project 
will  (i)  develop  an  efficient,  safe,  affordable,  and  environmentally 
sustainable railway transport system in the region; and (ii) help create 
more employment and income-generating opportunities, thus benefiting 
poor residents.  
   
Rationale  The Project reflects ADB’s railway sector operational strategy for the 
PRC, which includes reducing railway network constraints to promote 
sustainable economic growth in poor areas not served by railways. The 
components have been formulated in line with the Ministry of Railway’s 
(MOR’s) 2004 railway development plan and its 11FYP (2006–2010). 
 
CLR is in line with the Government’s western development strategy to 
provide  less-developed  regions  with  better  infrastructure  to  facilitate 
economic growth, thereby giving people more opportunities to improve 
their living standards. The interior regions of the PRC have not benefited 
as much from economic growth and reforms as the east coast; in fact, 
the  gap  between  economic  and  social  development  has  increased. 
Transport  constraints  and  high  logistics  costs  are  two  factors 
contributing to regional economic disparities, and two of the constraints 
preventing  the  western  region  from  capitalizing  on  its  comparative 
advantages. 
 
CLR  is  part  of  the  shortest  east–west  corridor  linking  Shanghai, 
Qingdao, Wuhan, Yichang, and other major cities and ports in the east 
to Chongqing and Chengdu in the west. The proposed alignment for the 
CLR is 369 km shorter than the existing route between Shanghai and 
Chengdu. Traversing Hubei province, and Chongqing municipality, the 
proposed  railway  line  will  connect  with  Shanghai–Wuhan–Yichang–
Lichuan  in  the  east,  Chongqing–Huaihua  railway  in  the  center,  the 
proposed Lanzhou–Chongqing and Xi’an–Chongqing main lines in the 
north, Chongqing–Chengdu in the west.

ii   
CLR,  a  joint-venture  railway  between  the  MOR  and  the  Chongqing 
municipal government, will have substantial managerial and financial 
autonomy. The Project will help change railway enterprises from cost 
centers  in  a  planned  economy  to  profit  centers  in  an  increasingly 
competitive transport market.  
   
Impact and  The Project will help increase standards of living and reduce poverty in 
Outcome  the  project  area  by  removing  a  transport  constraint  on  sustainable 
economic growth, and improve safety and reliability by introducing new 
and modern technology. This will be achieved through the provision of 
efficient,  affordable,  environment-friendly,  and  energy-efficient  railway 
transportation in unserved, less developed areas, creating the conditions 
necessary for developing local resources and generating employment 
and income-enhancing opportunities. 
 
Project preparation was participatory. Extensive consultations were held 
with  all  the  main  stakeholders—various  affected  people,  potential 
beneficiaries,  village  leaders,  women’s  groups,  local  ethnic  minority 
bureaus, and local governments in the project area. Household surveys 
were carried out and participatory workshops were organized in the 
project area to elicit and gain an understanding of public opinion about 
the  Project  and  provide  inputs  to  the  social  and  environmental 
assessments. 
 
The Project comprises (i) the construction of 259 km of double-track, 
electrified, standard-gauge Class I railway from Chongqing to Lichuan; 
(ii) the construction of eight new railway stations complete with facilities; 
(iii) safety initiatives, including the provision of modern technology and 
equipment  for  enhancing  safety;  (iv)  the  provision  of  signaling, 
communication, and management information systems; (v) training in 
the use and maintenance of modern equipment; (vi) consulting services 
for construction supervision, monitoring and evaluation, and marketing 
and business development; and (vii) institutional strengthening. The key 
inputs needed for project implementation are civil works, equipment, 
consultants, and MOR and project company staff. 
   
Project Investment  The total cost of the Project is $3,071.11 million.  
Plan 
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $150 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources will be 
provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility. The loan will have a term of 26 years including a grace 
period  of  6 years,  an  interest  rate  determined  according  to  ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15%, and other 
terms and conditions set forth in the Loan Agreement. 
   
Period of  Until 30 June 2015 
Utilization

iii 
Implementation  The Project will be implemented over 6 years. The Foreign Capital and 
Arrangements  Technical Import Center (FCTIC), under MOR, will coordinate the tasks 
of the project management office and be responsible for procurement, 
withdrawals, and reporting to ADB. The project company will construct, 
manage, and operate the CLR, and develop and implement adequate 
and  transparent  business  development  mechanisms,  and  accounting 
and reporting systems.  
   
Procurement  MOR  will  procure  ADB-financed  components  according  to  ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Contracts  for  goods  valued  at  $1  million  or  more  will  be  procured 
through international competitive bidding (ICB). Contracts valued at less 
than $1 million will be procured through national competitive bidding 
(NCB), according to the PRC Tendering and Bidding Law (1999) and 
subject to clarifications agreed on with ADB. Packages valued below 
$100,000, procurement will follow the shopping procedure.  
   
Consulting  The ADB loan will finance 8 person-months of international consulting 
Services  services  to  strengthen  the  institutional,  marketing,  and  business 
development  functions  of  the  project  company.  Consultants  will  be 
recruited through quality- and cost-based selection (80% technical and 
20% financial) and simplified technical proposal, according to ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). MOR will hire and finance the services of national consultants for 
project  design,  construction  supervision,  construction  quality  control, 
environmental supervision, procurement, and monitoring and evaluation 
of  the  safeguard  aspects  of  the  Project  according  to  government 
procedures acceptable to ADB. 
 
Project Benefits  The Project will (i) provide the shortest land route between Lichuan, 
and Beneficiaries  Fuling, and Chongqing—key economic centers of Chongqing and Hubei 
province—and enable railway users to benefit from lower transport costs 
and shorter travel distances and times; (ii) improve the environment and 
reduce  pollution;  (iii) enhance  railway  safety;  (iv)  reduce  fuel 
consumption and enhance energy efficiency, enabling the PRC to save 
valuable  foreign  exchange;  (v)  increase  the  corridor’s  capacity, 
benefiting consumers and producers of goods and services through the 
provision of timely and efficient transport services and lower logistics 
costs;  (vi) generate  direct  and  indirect  employment  in  the  project 
influence area, and create jobs and income-earning opportunities (many 
local unskilled laborers will be hired for the construction and operation of 
the railway); (vii) provide access to broader markets to an area that now 
lacks adequate cost-efficient transportation services; and (viii) stimulate 
local development through small-business opportunities, tourism, railway 
station  area  development,  and  other  infrastructure  elements,  to 
maximize benefits to local areas. 
 
The major project beneficiaries will be (i) the Government, which will 
benefit  from  the  reduced  energy  bill  and  improved  safety; 
(ii) passengers,  including  tourists,  who  will  benefit  from  affordable, 
faster,  and  safer  trips;  (iii) freight  users,  who  will  benefit  from  more 
affordable, faster, and safer trips when they switch from the existing 
road;  (iv) local  residents,  who  will  benefit  from  the  lower  prices  of

iv   
commodities and services transported by the project railway; (v) local 
labor involved in construction work and the supply of materials during 
implementation, and loading/unloading during the railway’s operation; 
(vi) local farmers, who will be able to sell their products at market prices 
without  paying  a  high  margin  to  a  transport  intermediary; 
(vii) manufacturers and traders, who can increase production capacity or 
establish businesses, and will transport their goods and services by the 
railway;  and  (viii) local  governments,  which  will  benefit  from  the 
increased  opportunity  for  local  area  development  and  increased 
revenues. 
 
The Project will benefit about 5.5 million people living in the project area. 
The poverty and social assessment looked at seven counties or districts. 
Two counties are designated national or provincial poverty counties. 
There are 681 poverty villages and about 590,000 people are poor. 
About 65% of the beneficiaries live in rural areas, and 16.4% are poor, 
with an annual net income per capita of less than CNY900. The links 
between poverty, difficult topography, and poor transport systems are 
apparent in the project area for the proposed CLR. Poverty is often 
caused  by  geographic  remoteness  and  isolation,  limited  transport 
access, high transport costs, and poor access to market information, as 
well as limited access to health, education, and other social services. 
 
The  Project  will  facilitate  the  creation  of  additional  employment  and 
income-generating opportunities. About 119,000 person-years of work 
will be created during construction. This will provide direct employment 
opportunities to over 59,500 poor people, including women and ethnic 
minorities. Railway station area development will increase incomes in 
local communities and help generate local revenues. The Project will 
facilitate  the  development  of  small  businesses,  local  industry,  and 
tourism, and thus help generate additional opportunities in the future for 
local  people.  Consultations  with  local  people  in  the  project  area 
indicated their strong support for the Project. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  and  economically  sustainable.  The  5.48% 
financial internal rate of return exceeds the 2.80% weighted average 
cost of capital. The economic internal rate of return is estimated at 
16.7%.  
 
The increased tax revenues generated by the economic development 
induced by the Project will help finance improved social service facilities 
and basic infrastructure. 
   
Risks and  The  railway  will  be  constructed  in  mountainous  and  difficult  terrain, 
Assumptions  which  presents  a  significant  technical  challenge.  The  associated 
  physical risks during implementation include delays, cost overruns, risks 
to worker health and safety, and environmental impact. These potential 
risks have been assessed and mitigating measures based on lessons 
learned from other railroad projects in the PRC have been provided.  
 
Resettlement  will  cause  the  relocation  of  about  5,314  people.  The 
railway  alignment  was  selected  to  minimize  resettlement,  where 
possible.  The  resettlement  plan  includes  preferential  treatment  for

v 
employment during construction, supply of local materials, allocation of 
commercial space near railway stations, and job training. Resettlement 
will be implemented by local governments and closely monitored and 
supervised.  These  measures  will  mitigate  the  potential  social  risks 
associated with resettlement. 
 
Intermodal competition between railways and roads will create market 
risks  for  the  project  railway.  However,  the  existing  road  is  already 
congested and the capacity constraint is expected to worsen. Surveys of 
passengers  and  freight  shippers  found  that  the  railway  would  have 
several advantages over other transport modes: lower fares, shorter 
travel  times,  safety,  and  punctuality.  The  increasing  commercial 
orientation of the joint-venture railway will help to lessen the risks posed 
by intermodal competition.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Chongqing–Lichuan  Railway  (CLR) 
Development Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced, to 2007, the PRC 
experienced  sustained  rapid  economic  growth,  which  resulted  in  a  correspondingly  rapid 
increase in demand for transportation. Passenger transport grew by 9% yearly and freight 
transport by 7.6%. The railway is the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC. In 2006, the 
modal split for freight ton-kilometers (km) was 47.5% for railways, 27.9% for inland waterways 
and sea-to-shore shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. That 
same year, road traffic accounted for 52.8% of total passenger-kilometers, railways for 34.5%, 
civil aviation for 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways for 0.4%.  
 
3.  The railway is the primary mode of transport for long-distance and bulk transport. At the 
end of 2007, the PRC’s railway system of 78,000 km comprised 63,600 km of national railways 
and 14,400 km of joint-venture and local railways. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) operates the 
state-owned national railway as an integrated system. The joint-venture and local railways, 
comprising regional lines within provincial boundaries, are constructed under the sponsorship of 
provincial governments or MOR to serve local needs and provide interconnection to the national 
railway network. The railway network, despite its large size, does not adequately cover the 
country’s population and land area.1 
 
4.  PRC’s  railways  have  the  highest  freight  transport  density  in  the  world  and  the 
second-highest passenger transport density after Japan’s. Locomotive turnover is the highest in 
the world. From 1978 to 2007, railway freight increased yearly by 5.28%, from 535 billion ton-km 
to  2,380 billion ton-km,  and  passenger  traffic  by  6.74%,  from  109 billion  passenger-km  to 
722 billion passenger-km. For passenger trips, the average railway journey increased from 134 
km in 1978 to 532 km in 2007; in comparison, the average road journey lengthened from 35 km 
to 55 km over the same period. For freight, the average journey in 2007 was 757 km for railway 
and 65 km for road. Despite such growth rates, railway capacity has lagged behind demand 
because of system constraints (Appendix 2). Given the railways’ important role in providing 
economic  transportation,  these  constraints,  if not  removed,  will  continue  to  thwart  efficient 
economic growth. The Government’s aggressive plan for improving railways includes network 
expansion and construction in underserved areas. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Government Strategy 
 
5.  The railway development policy of the Government of the PRC (Government) is directed 
at (i) removing constraints and expanding the system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint-
venture  local  railways  to  promote  the  development  of  local  economies,  (iii)  improving  the 
efficiency and safety of the existing system by using new technology and modern management

tools in planning and operation, (iv) reducing operating subsidies through appropriate pricing 
and commercialization of services, (v) initiating institutional and structural reforms to increase 
autonomy and accountability, and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure 
and related services.  
 
6.  In 2004, the State Council approved a new railway development plan for the period up to 
2020. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 100,000 km. Increasing train speed is a 
major goal. Priority will be given to developing railways in unserved areas and regions that now 
lack transport and are still less developed. The route network length will increase by 16,000 km 
in the western region of the PRC, to reach a network length of 40,000 km by 2020. To improve 
operational efficiency, MOR has begun separating passenger and freight trains on key rail 
corridors.2  
 
7.  The Eleventh Five-Year Plan (11FYP) (2006–2010) continues to emphasize railway 
development,  and  seeks  to  speed  up  railway  construction.  The  plan  envisages  (i)  the 
construction of 17,000 km of new lines, and (ii) the double-tracking and electrification of 45% of 
the network length. The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger railway network through 
the construction of 7,000 km of passenger dedicated lines by 2010; (ii) develop coal transport 
corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway network in the 
poor western region (to 34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at the southwest and 
northwest  borders;  and  (v)  develop  a  nationwide  intermodal  container  network.  A  total 
investment of CNY1.5 trillion—CNY1.25 trillion for construction and CNY250 billion for rolling 
stock—is planned in the 11FYP, of which a total of CNY465.2 billion has been spent in 2006 
and 2007 (Appendix 3). 
 
2.  Asian Development Bank Strategy and Sector Experience 
 
8.  The strategy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the railway sector involves 
helping (i) expand the railway system by constructing new lines in unserved, less-developed 
areas; (ii) modernize railways, enhance safety, and increase the capacity to improve efficiency 
on key routes of the national railway system; (iii) commercialize railway operations to sustain 
efficient operations; (iv) promote energy conservation and environmental sustainability; and 
(v) increase railway competitiveness in the transport sector through restructuring and reform. At 
the heart of the strategy is the development of railways in poor, less-developed inland provinces 
to promote sustainable economic growth and reduce poverty.3 ADB has provided 15 loans 
totaling over $3.0 billion to finance the construction of about 1,921 km of eight provincial 
railways operated by joint ventures with MOR, and 5,541 km of new railway lines under six 
national railway projects, and a sector-wide intervention to improve safety on the PRC railway 
network. ADB assistance to the sector has evolved from financing civil works on local railways 
to supporting major national corridors with much less financing but with safety, management 
information system, environmental, and other technological improvements (Appendix 4). The 
Project,  designed  to  promote  economic  growth  by  providing  safe  and  reliable  railway 
transportation  in  unserved,  less-developed,  and  poor  areas  of  Chongqing  municipality  and 
Hubei province, is consistent with the PRC’s development priorities and the ADB strategy.

9.  Policy Dialogue. Policy dialogue has been a feature of ADB’s assistance to the railway 
sector and has effectively complemented the lending operations. Since 1989, 14 technical 
assistance (TA) initiatives totaling $6.6 million have been provided for institutional development 
for dedicated passenger lines and local railways, tariff and organizational studies for the Jing–
Jiu railway, enhancement of commercial and business operations, marketing and business 
development, human resource development, and improvement of financial management and 
accounting systems. ADB’s policy dialogue with MOR is centered on (i) poverty reduction as the 
overarching  objective  of  ADB  operations,  (ii)  full  compliance  with  ADB  safeguard  policies, 
(iii) energy conservation and environmental sustainability, (iv) railway safety, (v) sector reforms, 
(vi) marketing and business development, (vii) private sector participation and nongovernment 
financing, and (viii) regional cooperation. The railway development plan defines the major goals 
for the PRC railways up to 2020, and is in broad agreement with ADB’s strategic agenda. 
MOR’s  proposed  reform  agenda  for  this  plan  seeks  to  (i)  study  and  learn  from  the  best 
international  practices  worldwide,  (ii)  separate  core  operations  from  noncore  transportation 
businesses, (iii) rationalize and reduce staff, (iv) reform the railway investment and financing 
system, and (v) establish specialized transportation companies. 
 
10.  MOR  is  taking  a  structured  approach  to  railway  reform.  In  1999,  using  a  new 
management  concept—the  asset  operating  liability  system—it  entered  into  management 
contracts with railway administrations to improve profitability (as a pilot project). The contracts 
helped  improve  operational  and  financial  performance;  this  approach  was  subsequently 
extended to all railway administrations. The separation of core and noncore businesses is a key 
element  of  MOR’s  restructuring  program.  The  total  number  of  employees  in  the  core 
transportation business was reduced from 1.89 million in 1997 to 1.41 million in 2006. In the 
noncore  transportation business,  five  large  companies  employing  616,500  staff  have  been 
divested.  To  provide  jobs  for  redundant  staff,  by  the  end  of  2006  MOR  had  set  up 
3,625 diversified businesses (independent of the core transportation business) employing more 
than 321,544 staff to supply equipment, goods, and services to the railway industry. In 1998, 
MOR initiated a cost-sharing scheme for health insurance and pensions for railway employees. 
In 2005, it completed the transfer of 822 primary and middle schools, 46 vocational schools, and 
181 nursery schools, and 260 hospitals and medical units to local governments. One hundred 
branch lines comprising 7,800 km were separated to improve productivity and reduce operating 
losses. (The reform agenda matrix is in Appendix 5. Supplementary Appendix A contains a 
chronology of railway reforms.)

13.  Enhancing Safety. Safety is an integral part of a competitive, high-quality, and reliable 
transportation system for people and goods. As PRC railways have modernized, introduced new 
concepts and technologies, and increased speeds, the safety needs have changed. MOR’s 
11FYP recognizes this important aspect and seeks to attract foreign technology and know-how 
to meet these needs. ADB, for its part, emphasizes in its policy dialogue with MOR the need for 
operational  reforms  for  the  rail  network,  including  safety  improvements  in  construction, 
operation, and maintenance. MOR and ADB support the objective of safety and security on 
PRC railways through the introduction of modern technologies, policy development, legislation, 
monitoring  and  enforcement,  and  outreach  activities  (Appendix  6).  Since  2003,  ADB  has 
supported investments in railway safety as part of ADB financing. ADB has initiated dialogue on 
adopting a sector-wide approach, rather than a project-based approach, to safety. A sector-wide 
approach is consistent with the network approach adopted for train operations in the PRC and 
helps in providing economies of scale, and better management of emergencies, preventive 
maintenance,  and  accidents.  ADB  has  worked  closely  with  the  safety  and  transportation 
departments of MOR to develop a comprehensive plan for the institutional, investment, and 
training needs for safety in PRC railways and is providing a TA grant of $500,000 to help in 
developing an emergency management system.7 In 2007, ADB approved a $100 million loan for 
enhancing safety on the PRC railway network.8

14.  Sector  Reforms. ADB is supporting the institutional reform of the railway sector to 
separate government and enterprise functions, giving full play to market forces and increasing 
the competitiveness of the railways. ADB has actively pursued (i) the separation of the core 
transport business from the noncore transport business, (ii) the segmentation of passenger and

companies.  As  part  of  ADB’s  policy  dialogue  with  MOR,  three  large  companies  handling

passenger-dedicated corridors with a separate institutional structure is a key ADB intervention.10 
ADB is assisting in the development of the institutional, marketing, business development, and 
technical standards for such initiatives.11  
 
15.  Rationalization of staff and reduction of transportation and non-transportation staff is 
also being pursued. On 18 March 2005, under a major restructuring exercise, MOR abolished

end of 2006, the number of stations and sections had been reduced from 1,500 to 695. In the 
process, the staff was reduced by 22,000, operations were rationalized, productivity improved, 
and efficiency increased. Recent ADB interventions have supported operational reforms and 
emphasized railway safety, including the introduction of safe and reliable technology, faster 
speeds,  dedicated  passenger  and  freight  lines,  a  modern  dispatch  control  system,  and 
high-quality information systems on the PRC railway network. The PRC’s accession to the 
World Trade Organization has intensified competition among different modes of transport, and 
the structure of transport demand is likely to change.12 An ADB advisory TA for policy reform 
support to MOR13 analyzed (i) the conflicting roles of meeting social obligations and making 
profits, (ii) increasing modal competition, (iii) the impact of fast urbanization and economic 
development, and (iv) demand for better services. As a lead development partner in the sector, 
ADB maintains close coordination with AFD, KfW, and the World Bank; and has developed with 
these institutions a common approach to reforms and assistance (Appendix 3).

4.  Rationale 
22.  The  project  rationale  reflects  (i)  network  development;  (ii) capacity  enhancement; 
(iii) safety enhancement; (iv) support for the PRC railway development plan and the western 
region development strategy; and (v) promotion of pro-poor economic growth along the railway 
line and in the region, thereby reducing poverty. The Project will pursue the operational reforms, 
including  emphasis  on  safety  and  the  introduction  of  safe  and  reliable  technology,  faster 
speeds, double-stack container operation under an electrified line, modern dispatch control 
systems, and high-quality information systems on the railway network. 
 
23.  The proposed CLR is part of the shortest east–west corridor linking Shanghai, Qingdao, 
Wuhan, Yichang, and other major cities and ports in the east to Chongqing and Chengdu in the 
west. The proposed alignment for the CLR is 369 km shorter than the existing route between 
Shanghai and Chengdu. Traversing Hubei province, and Chongqing municipality, the proposed 
railway  line  will  connect  with  Shanghai–Wuhan–Yichang–Lichuan  in  the  east,  Chongqing–
Huaihua railway in the center, the proposed Lanzhou–Chongqing24 and Xi’an–Chongqing main 
lines in the north, Chongqing–Chengdu in the west, and Chongqing–Kunming in the south. 
 
24.  The project area for Chongqing–Lichuan is largely mountainous, with abundant natural 
reserves of coal, natural gas, nonferrous materials, and famous tourist sites. But despite the 
abundant natural resources, many people are poor and the economic growth necessary to 
reduce rural poverty has failed to materialize because of inadequate transport services and high 
costs.  Local  governments  and  people  living  in  the  project  area  see  the  railway  as  a  key 
investment for addressing this problem. The development of the railway line and associated 
developments are expected to stimulate industrial and natural resources development, promote 
tourism and related industries, generate employment and increase living standards, and help to 
reduce  poverty.  The  Project  is  a  part  of  the  Government’s  program  for  the  integrated 
development of transportation facilities, which includes the project railway, the upgrading of 
highways, and the construction of link and access roads to the hinterland. Other infrastructure, 
such as water supply and investment to improve education and health care facilities, are also 
planned. The railway will play an important role in facilitating the development and integration of 
this poor and underdeveloped region. 
 
25.  CLR will be a joint-venture railway owned and operated by MOR and the Chongqing 
municipal government. Joint-venture railways, which account for 9,517 km (2007) of the PRC 
system,  have  substantial  managerial  and  financial  autonomy,  including  the  freedom  to  set 
tariffs, which are several times higher than those of the national network. Freight and passenger 
traffic on joint-venture railways have grown faster than on national railways. Between 1996 and 
2007, passenger traffic grew from 2.2 billon passenger-km to 31.5 billion passenger-km (or by 
28% yearly, compared with 7% on the national railway network), and freight traffic rose from 
12.3 billion ton-km to 155.2 billion ton-km (or by 26.5% yearly, compared with 5% on the 
national railway network). Joint-venture railways are more efficient, employing only 8–10 people 
per km, compared with about 25 people per km for national railways. The project company will 
employ 8–10 people per km.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
27.  The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  an  improved  transport  system  in  the  Shanghai–
Chengdu  corridor  that  supports  socioeconomic  development  and  the  western  development 
strategy. This will be achieved through the provision of efficient, affordable, environment-friendly 
and  energy-efficient  railway  transportation  in  unserved,  less-developed  areas,  creating  the 
conditions necessary for developing local resources and generating employment and income-
enhancing opportunities.  
 
B.  Outputs 
28.  The  Project  comprises  (i)  the  construction  of  259  km  of  double-track,  electrified, 
standard-gauge Class I railway from Chongqing to Lichuan; (ii) the construction of eight new 
railway stations complete with facilities; (iii) safety initiatives, including the provision of modern 
technology and equipment to enhance safety; (iv) the provision of signaling, communication, 
and management information systems; (v) training in the use and maintenance of modern 
equipment; (vi) consulting services for construction supervision, monitoring and evaluation, and 
marketing  and  business  development;  and  (vii)  institutional  strengthening.  The  key  inputs 
needed for project implementation are civil works, equipment, consultants, MOR, and project 
company staff (see Supplementary Appendix B for characteristics of the Chongqing–Lichuan 
Railway).  
 
C.  Special Features 
29.  Energy Benefits. Railways are a more energy-efficient and environment-friendly mode 
of transport than road transport—6–10 times more efficient, by some estimates. The rolling 
resistance of a steel wheel on a rail is much less than that of rubber tires on a pavement. The 
United States Department of Energy has estimated25 the energy intensity of rail freight at 
345 British thermal units (BTU) per ton-mile and road freight at 3,476 BTU per ton-mile. This

31.  Intermodal Transport or Container Transport. The Project will promote railway and 
multimodal transport of goods in the region by introducing double-stack container operation 
under an electrified track, which will reduce land use, increase carrying capacity by 60% on the

Wuhan  to  (i)  attract  high-value  traffic  on  the  railways;  (ii)  promote  intermodal  traffic;  and 
(iii) encourage private sector shippers and freight forwarders to use the facility for export and 
import of cargo to other parts of the PRC, and ports in the east and Yunnan in the south. The 
construction of these container terminals will be financed by MOR and completed by 2010. 
 
32.  Corporate Governance. ADB’s policy reform agenda in the railway sector emphasizes 
MOR restructuring, commercial operations, support for the autonomous management of railway 
operations,  human  resources  development,  and  improved  financial  management  and 
accounting systems. The setting up of the joint-venture railways is a key ADB intervention. 
Under the Project, a corporate entity has been set up and its capacity development will be 
supported.  ADB-financed  consulting  services  will  assist  in  strengthening  the  institutional, 
marketing, and business development functions of the project company. 
 
33.  Opportunities for the Private Sector. The project company will outsource activities 
such as consulting services for construction supervision, testing, construction contracts, track 
maintenance, and industrial sidings by open competition. Private sector initiatives such as 
onboard  train  services  (including  catering,  cleaning,  and  loading  and  unloading  at  railway 
stations) will be promoted. Station space will be developed and rented out by open competition, 
and industrial sidings, hotels, restaurants, and other logistic facilities will be encouraged in the 
vicinity of stations.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
53.  The project benefits and impact have been assessed, along with the potential risks 
associated with the Project. The combined benefits and impact will outweigh the costs, and net 
benefits will accrue to the project area. 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
54.  The traffic forecast is based on forecasts prepared by the Second Survey and Design 
Institute and the assessment of TA consultants after considering expected economic growth, 
population increase, tourism development potential, local government development plans, and 
market  surveys.  The  passenger  volume  on  the  CLR  is  forecast  to  grow  from  8.38 billion 
passenger-km in 2014 to 25.78 billion passenger-km in 2033, for an average growth rate of 
6.4% yearly. The freight traffic on the CLR corridor is forecast, on the basis of similar factors, to 
increase from about 7.16 billion ton-km in 2014 to 20.13 billion ton-km in 2033, or by 5.9% 
yearly.  The  projected  volumes  can  be  accommodated  by  the  CLR  and  justify  project 
construction. 
 
B.  Economic Benefits 
55.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated through a comparison of the 
with- and without-project situations, using constant 2008 economic prices. The CLR will reduce 
the  cost  of  transport  to  and  from  the  poor  parts  of  Chongqing  and  Hubei  province.  The 
economic  costs  include  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance  costs,  and  the  value  of 
agricultural production from land lost permanently. The economic benefits include (i) operating 
cost savings for freight and passenger traffic; (ii) time saved as a result of the diversion of 
passenger  traffic  from  buses  trucks,  and  other  rail  lines;  (iii)  transport  benefits  generated; 
(iv) tourism benefits; (v) road infrastructure and maintenance costs avoided; (vi) shipper savings 
resulting  from  increased  railway  competition;  (vii)  road  accidents  avoided;  (viii)  reduced 
pollution; (ix) energy savings; and (x) national productivity benefits. The project EIRR is 16.7%, 
indicating that the Project is economically viable (Appendix 14). Sensitivity analysis confirms the 
robustness of the Project’s economic viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 20% 
reduction in benefits, do not significantly affect economic viability. The civil works cost would 
have to increase by 60.0% over the estimate for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. 
Freight benefits would have to fall by 44.0% and passenger benefits by 936.8%. Given the 
experience in the PRC railway sector, variations of such magnitude are unlikely. Project risks 
were quantified through the statistical method, i.e., by considering the possible value for key 
variables and the probability of their occurrence. The result shows minimal probability of EIRR 
falling  below  12%.  Distribution  analysis,  undertaken  by  determining  the  project  effects  for 
various beneficiaries, indicates that a large portion of net benefits will accrue to project users 
and the economy. 
 
C.  Financial Benefits 
56.  Financial  projections  were  prepared  for  the  project  company,  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Analysis  and  Management  of  Projects  (2005),  to  assess  the 
financial viability and sustainability of the railway. The projected financial statements indicate 
that financial revenues will be sufficient to cover operation and maintenance costs, income

17 
taxes, and debt service, and to provide a reasonable rate of return. The financial evaluation was 
undertaken in real terms, using constant 2008 prices. The project cost estimates and financial 
projections in nominal terms were converted to real terms by adjusting for the projected effects 
of foreign and domestic inflation and currency fluctuation. Incremental costs and benefits were 
derived under with- and without-project scenarios. The financial internal rate of return, after tax, 
is 5.48%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital, also after tax, of 
2.80%. The Project is both financially viable and sustainable. Sensitivity and risk analyses 
indicate that the financial internal rate of return for the Project is robust under most conditions.

E.  Impact on Poverty 
61.  The railway will traverse seven districts and counties in the eastern part of Chongqing 
city and one county in the western part of Hubei province; two of these are designated national 
or provincial poverty counties. The Project will benefit about 5.5 million people in the project 
area; of these, 3.6 million (65%) are in the countryside and include 590,000 poor people 
(16.4%) with a net income per capita of less than CNY900 in 2005. There are 681 designated 
poverty villages, many of which lack access to potable water. Poverty is concentrated in the 
three counties (Fengdu, Shizhu and Lichuan) farthest from Chongqing, which are isolated by 
mountains  and  poor  transport  facilities.  The  links  between  poverty,  topography,  and  poor 
transport systems are apparent in the project area. Poverty in this area is caused by (i) adverse 
environmental and weather conditions and limited farmland (e.g., mountains, water scarcity, and 
soil erosion); (ii) geographical remoteness and isolation, and high transport costs; (iii) limited 
access to credit for rural enterprises; (iv) lack of access to good social and health-care facilities; 
and (v) high cost of middle- and higher-level education. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Appendix 16.

62.  During construction, about 119,000 person-years of work will be created for unskilled 
laborers; of this total 50% or more (59,500 person-years with total wages of CNY446 million) will 
be targeted at the poor. The use of locally produced materials for railway construction will 
generate an additional 22,000 person-years of work for unskilled laborers, with total wages of 
CNY165.5 million. The construction tax revenue will be reallocated to counties and used for a

CNY35.3 million annually. The project’s eight new railway stations will be connected to the road 
network accessible by all villages, including the poor, and will create various jobs, thus helping 
distribute the benefits in the project area. There will be enough space in and around the stations 
for local area development, and local governments will support the poor, women, ethnic groups, 
and other vulnerable people in setting up shop and selling local specialties and other goods and 
services. The new railway will provide significantly cheaper and more affordable transportation 
compared to roads. All of this direct and indirect impact will provide opportunities for poor 
families to (i) move away from unsustainable, mountainous farmlands; (ii) provide a cheaper 
mode  of  travel;  (iii)  have  better  access  to markets,  and  advanced  educational  and  health 
facilities, especially for women; and (iv) build a sustainable future in new centers of economic 
activity. 
 
F.  Resettlement Impact 
63.  The project railway alignment will affect 29 townships and 84 villages as it passes 
through  the  seven districts  and  counties  that  compose  the  project  area.  An  estimated 
711 hectares of land will be permanently acquired; about 62.3% of this is now under cultivation 
and the rest (37.1%) is predominately forestland. Since the railway will require only a narrow 
corridor, the average loss of land per household is estimated to be 15%; this means that about 
35,000 persons will be partially affected. The Project will temporarily occupy an estimated 
674 hectares during construction. Also, 391,000 square meters of structures will be demolished; 
of  these,  86%  will  be  residential  structures,  and  5,314  persons  will  therefore  have  to  be 
relocated. The summary resettlement plan is shown in Appendix 17. 
 
64.  MOR,  in  consultation  with  the  provincial  and  local  governments,  has  prepared  a

endorsed by MOR and uploaded to the ADB website on 4 September 2007. MOR will submit an 
updated resettlement plan to ADB by 15 December 2008. MOR and municipal land acquisition

during construction. The project area has much smaller numbers of HIV/AIDS-infected people 
than  other  parts  of  the  PRC,  according  to  discussions  with  local  health  bureaus.  Local 
governments have an active public information program for HIV/AIDS awareness, including the 
distribution of leaflets and posters, and radio and television programs. The health departments 
in these provinces have carried out awareness programs, HIV/AIDS/STIs voluntary counseling 
and testing, and prevention programs; these will be stepped up and monitored closely. During 
the construction period, the county governments along the alignment will raise public awareness 
among workers and communities. MOR has experience in ensuring that contractors implement 
awareness and prevention programs. Medical clinics have been established in the area of 
construction camps, and HIV/AIDS awareness campaigns and preventive measures for workers 
and communities have been organized. These measures have effectively managed the potential 
risks of HIV/AIDS/STI transmission and other diseases, and will be applied to the Project.  
 
68.  An SDAP has been prepared in consultation with local governments to enhance the 
project benefits; ensure that adverse impact is avoided or mitigated; and increase economic 
development benefits to the poor, women, Tujia people, and the vulnerable in an equitable and 
sustainable manner (Appendix 18). The SDAP will (i) enhance job opportunities for local people; 
(ii) provide training and vocational programs for the poor, women, ethnic minorities, and the 
vulnerable; (iii) support HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention programs; (iv) support income 
recovery programs for people affected by resettlement; (v) provide awareness and prevention 
programs  for  safety  during  construction  and  operation;  and  (vi)  promote  local  economic 
development.  The  plan  will  be  implemented  with  the  participation  of  relevant  government

20 
agencies  at  the  local  level—including  poverty  alleviation  offices,  the  All-China  Women’s 
Federation, and health, civil affairs, labor, and ethnic affairs bureaus. Leading groups have been 
formed to continue the process of consultation and coordination among various agencies during 
implementation. 
 
H.  Risks and Assumptions 
69.  The Project has been formulated to minimize potential risks. In view of the experience 
with previous railway projects, traffic demand has been estimated conservatively. Sensitivity 
tests indicate that economic circumstances would have to become substantially adverse for the 
Project to lose economic viability. A potential risk is delay in implementation, which would delay 
the realization of benefits. MOR has successfully built railway lines, such as the Ganzhou–
Longyan, Hefei–Xi’an, and Jing–Jiu railways. Government, MOR, CMG support for the Project 
and  its  preparation  contributes  to  reducing  the  potential  risk  of  implementation  delays. 
Environmental risks will be mitigated by the measures in the environmental management plan 
(EMP) and will be closely monitored during project implementation. 
 
70.  Intermodal competition among railways and roads will create market risks for the project 
railway. However, the existing road is already congested and capacity constraints are expected 
to worsen. Traffic surveys indicate that the railway has several advantages: lower fares, shorter 
travel times, safety, and punctuality. The increasing commercial orientation of the joint-venture 
railway will help lower the risks posed by intermodal competition.

RAILWAY SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Railway Sector Profile 
 
1.  Key Features. Despite government efforts to increase the country’s transport capacity, 
serious constraints and bottlenecks remain, especially in the road and railway sectors. By the 
end of 2007, the PRC’s railway system of 78,000 kilometers (km) comprised 63,600 km of 
national railways and 14,400 km of joint venture and local railways.  From 1978, when economic 
reforms were first introduced, to 2007, the PRC experienced sustained rapid economic growth. 
This resulted in a correspondingly rapid increase in demand for transportation. Passenger 
transport grew by 9% yearly and freight transport by 7.6% yearly during the period. Railways are 
the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, accounting for 47.5% of total freight ton-
kilometers (ton-km) in 2006, followed by 27.9% for inland waterways and sea-to-shore shipping, 
21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. Road traffic accounted for 
52.8% of total passenger-kilometers (pass-km), followed by railways with 34.5%, civil aviation 
with 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%.  
 
2.  Recent  Developments.  To  minimize  transport  inefficiencies  and  eliminate  transport 
bottlenecks  that  constrain  efficient  economic  development,  the  Government  increased  its 
investment  in  transport  infrastructure  in  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  and  the 
11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). Investment in transport infrastructure as a share of gross 
domestic  product  (GDP)  more  than  doubled  in  the  last  decade.  The  PRC  had  invested 
CNY308 billion in capital construction to build 6,458 km of new lines, provide 3,275 km of 
double lines, and electrify 6,259 km of tracks in the 10th Five-Year Plan. A World Bank study1 
indicates that total transport investment should increase to at least 3.8% of GDP to avoid the 
economic costs associated with transport constraints. The Government continues to accord high 
priority to transport infrastructure investments to meet the increase in transport demand. 
 
3.  Future Development Priorities and Outlook. Substantial investments in the road and 
railway sectors from both domestic and international financing sources, including the private 
sector, are envisaged in the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). The plan continues to emphasize 
railway  development,  and  seeks  to  accelerate  railway  construction.  It  envisages  (i) the 
construction of 17,000 km of new lines, and (ii) the double-tracking and electrification of 45% of 
the network length. The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger railway network by 
constructing  7,000  km  of  passenger-dedicated  lines  by  2010;  (ii)  develop  coal  transport 
corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway network in the 
poor western region (to 34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at the southwest and 
northwest  borders;  and  (v)  develop  a  nationwide  intermodal  container  network.  A  total 
investment of CNY1.5 trillion (CNY1.25 trillion for construction and CNY250 billion for rolling 
stock) is planned in the 11th Five-Year Plan, of which a total of CNY465.2 billion has been spent 
in 2006 and 2007.

increasing the capacity to improve transport efficiency on key routes of the national railway 
system, (iii) commercializing railway operations to sustain efficient operations, (iv) promoting 
energy  conservation  and  environmental  sustainability,  and  (v) increasing  railway 
competitiveness in the transport system through restructuring and reform.  
 
9.  Poverty Reduction. To heighten the poverty reduction impact of transport investments, 
ADB  pays  particular  attention  to  four  issues:  (i) locating  ADB-financed  projects  in 
less-developed  and  poor  regions  where  new  lines  will  stimulate  economic  development, 
(ii) encouraging the maximization of employment of poor people during project construction and 
operation, (iii) supplying local materials that meet the requirements of quality and economy from 
poor villages, and (iv) providing station access roads and link roads to widen the reach of 
project benefits to poor interior areas. 
 
10.  Governance and Policy Reform Agenda. The ADB policy reform agenda in the railway 
sector  is  contributing  to  the  restructuring  of  the  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR),  the 
commercialization of operations, the increased management autonomy of railway operations, 
human resource  development, and improvements in financial management and accounting 
systems. ADB’s policy dialogue with MOR emphasizes the need for operational reforms for the 
rail  network,  including  enhancing  safety  in  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance.  ADB 
supports the safety and security objective on PRC railways through the introduction of modern 
technologies, policy development, legislation, monitoring, and outreach activities (Appendix 6). 
 
11.  Private  Sector  Development.  The  PRC’s  large  infrastructure  needs  require  local 
governments to shift from traditional financing modes to the capital markets. In the railway 
sector, a wider role for the private sector is envisaged. MOR has taken steps to create the 
conditions  necessary  to  attract  investments  in  the  project  facilities  and  services  from 
nongovernment and private sector sources. Possible areas include the construction of industrial 
sidings, commercial services, tourism, containerization, and parcel-related businesses. 
 
12.  Regional Cooperation. The PRC is an active participant in three regional cooperation 
initiatives: (i) the Greater Mekong Subregion, through Yunnan and Guangxi province; (ii) the

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The objective of the Chongqing–Lichuan Railway is to promote sustainable economic 
growth  by  enhancing  transportation  capability  in  an  unserved  area,  thereby  creating

achieve this objective, a corporate entity is being set up to construct, operate, and manage the 
Project,  and  to  assist  in  facilitating  economic  developments,  such  as  tourism,  as  well  as 
value-added and labor-intensive industries in the project area. The consulting services will 
assist in strengthening the institutional, marketing, and business development functions of the 
Project.  
 
B.   Scope 
 
2.  The consultants will (i) help with the institutional strengthening of the project company for 
its successful operation in a market environment; (ii) determine the level of tourism, industry, 
and market development expertise of the project company; (iii) undertake research on programs 
and incentives available for attracting tourist and related industry at the county, prefecture, and 
province levels; (iv) meet with a selection of potential shippers located or planning to locate 
along the route of the Chongqing–Lichuan Railway; (v) meet with businesspeople of Changshu,

requirements;  (vi) develop  plans  for  improving  railway  services  for  passengers  (including 
tourists)  and  freight  (particularly  container  services);  (vii) propose  measures  to  develop

institutional efforts and provide capacity development support to make the project company

TRAFFIC FORECAST AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
1.  Freight traffic for the Chongqing–Lichuan Railway (CLR) was forecast by commodity 
(i.e.,  coal,  petroleum  products,  iron  and  steel,  fertilizers,  intermodal  containers,  and  other 
commodities) in two categories differentiated by their economic impact: (i) traffic diverted from 
other modes (other railway routes, roads, and inland waterway) based on an assessment of the 
relative service- and cost-competitiveness of the project railway; and (ii) generated traffic that 
would only move because of the existence of a railway line where none previously existed. The 
traffic  forecast  was  based  on  a  two-tier  analysis:  (i)  national  transport  demand  based  on 
historical trends correlating socioeconomic parameters, such as gross domestic product and 
propensity to travel or ship or demand for railway transport; (ii) national and regional railway 
traffic demand based on commodity-specific analysis for major commodities currently using 
 
other  railway  lines,  roads,  and  inland  waterways. Traffic  projections  considered  expected 
economic  growth,  population  increase,  tourism  development  potential,  local  government 
development plans, market surveys, and assessments of technical assistance consultants and 
Asian Development Bank missions. The freight volume on the CLR is forecast to increase from 
about 7.16 billion ton-kilometers (ton-km) in 2014 to 20.13 billion ton-km in 2033, for an average 
 
annual growth rate of 5.9%.Passenger traffic is forecast to grow from 8.38 billion passenger-
kilometers  (passenger-km)  in  2014  to  25.78  billion  passenger-km  in 2033,  for  an  average 
annual growth rate of 6.4% (Table A14.1). Traffic forecasts are considered reasonable, given 
that (i) the CLR is an important link along the Chengdu–Chongqing–Shanghai transport corridor, 
connecting western People’s Republic of China (PRC) with the east, as well as serving as a 
gateway to the PRC–Eurasian rail network for intermodal transport; (ii) railways in the PRC have 
experienced high annual traffic growth with recent rates higher than the assumed growth rates 
for freight and passenger traffic; (iii) the existing parallel road within the project corridor is 
congested  in  some  areas,  making  road  transport  expensive  and  hazardous;  and  (iv)  the 
distance saved by routing traffic through CLR compared with other railway lines is up to 369 km 
in  origin–destination  pairs  involving  long-distance  movement  between  eastern  and  western 
PRC.  
 
B.   Economic Evaluation  
2.  Analysis  of  Alternatives.  As  part  of  the  economic  analysis,  possible  alternative 
interventions were considered, to meet the growing transport demand in the project area as part 
of the national and provincial transport network plan. Various options, in terms of transport 
modes, alignments, and technical designs, were reviewed. While enhancing the existing road 
capacity may be an option to partly meet the increasing demand, it will not completely satisfy 
the various kinds of traffic, particularly bulk cargo such as coal over long distances to meet the 
needs of a growing economy. Aside from the higher initial cost, increased land requirements, 
high air pollution, fuel consumption, and user costs make the road alternative less viable. 
Multiple alignment alternatives were subsequently evaluated for four line sections, considering 
geologic  and  topographic  conditions,  terrain,  the  results  of  consultations  with  community 
representatives, cost estimates, relative impact on the environment and resettlement, and the 
objective of integration with the national and local transport network. The technical design was 
proposed after consideration of the national railway network, consistency in the standards of 
contiguous sections at each end of the project railway, and forecast traffic.  
 
3.  Cost. The economic evaluation is based on a comparison of with- and without-project 
scenarios,  using  constant  2008  economic  prices.  Under  the  without-project  scenario  it  is 
assumed  that  the  diverted  traffic  (27.3  million  tons  and  26.1  million  passengers  by  2014)

estimated  under  the  with-project scenario  would  continue  moving  by  road  and  by  existing 
railway lines. Furthermore, the generated traffic estimated under the with-project scenario (3.79 
million  tons  and  16.41  million  passengers  by  2014)  would  not  materialize  under  the 
without-project scenario. The project benefits and cost were revalued in economic prices by 
separating the cost items into tradable materials and equipment, non-tradable materials, labor,

factories will only suffer partial impact and continue operations at the same site. For factories 
required to relocate, each owner will prepare a relocation plan, which includes the restoration of 
livelihood and incomes for all workers. Schools and other institutions will be rebuilt according to 
the plans of local government, to ensure that service levels are maintained or improved. 
 
4.  The resettlement impact of the railway project is spread thinly over a long, narrow 
corridor.  Investigations  showed  that  income  loss  from  land  acquisition  will  be  less  severe

Appendix 17  59 
because this corridor is developing rapidly and at least 70% of net income for more than half of 
rural  households  comes  from  nonagricultural  employment  and  small  businesses.  Special 
assistance will be provided to any seriously affected villages and groups, especially vulnerable 
households that include the poor, widows, and disabled persons. Ethnic minorities (primarily 
Tujia) account for 14% of the project beneficiaries and less than 10% of affected persons. Some 
of Tujia households have successfully transitioned into the PRC’s economy, while others have 
remained poor, albeit with improved living conditions. Where they are poor, this is due to the 
limited  resources  available  in  the  area  to  all  residents  and  inability  to  take  advantage  of 
opportunities. Special measures are included in the resettlement plan to ensure that they are 
adequately rehabilitated and that their living standards improve.  
 
5.  Local  government  land  administration  bureaus  will  be  responsible  for  implementing 
resettlement; many activities will be carried out by township officials and village committees. 
MOR and the local governments have extensive experience, and they integrate resettlement 
with project implementation through railway construction support offices, which have already 
been set up. Local government will provide training to local officials who will be involved in 
implementation. The training will focus on ADB requirements, as specified in the resettlement 
plan, and new domestic procedures. Affected persons have been informed and consulted about 
the project impact and resettlement policies and entitlements at various stages. Resettlement 
information  booklets  have  been  distributed  to  affected  villages.  Affected  households  will 
continue to be consulted and are encouraged to participate in resettlement activities, including 
the detailed measurement survey, location of underpasses, new housing sites, and grievance 
redress. 
 
6.  Affected households will receive training and skills development assistance that will 
facilitate income-generating activities. Other assistance, such as preferential hiring of affected 
persons by construction companies and access to credit, will also be provided. Local poverty 
alleviation programs provide a valuable source of additional assistance to vulnerable groups 
and they will be targeted during the implementation of the resettlement plan. In addition, the 
provinces  have  established  programs  that  directly  benefit  affected  villages  and  persons. 
Chongqing has a very active village development program that provides infrastructure and funds 
for rural enterprise development that will be doubled during the Eleventh Five-Year Plan.  
 
7.  The total resettlement cost for the Project is CNY541.35 million, including taxes and 
contingencies. The Chongqing municipal government will finance the resettlement cost for its 
section of the railway and MOR will finance the section in Lichuan. Both have guaranteed to 
supplement  the  resettlement  budget,  as  may  prove  necessary,  to  meet  any  shortfall.  An 
implementation schedule based on MOR’s project construction timetable has been prepared. 
Land acquisition and housing demolition for the railway component would commence in the first 
quarter of 2009, and the work on new stations would start much later. The Project is expected to 
be completed in 2014. 
 
8.  MOR, through the project company, and the local governments, through the railway 
construction  support  offices,  will  be  responsible  for  internal  supervision  and  monitoring  of 
compensation payments, house rebuilding and relocation, land redistribution, and grievance 
redress. MOR and the local governments have extensive experience in land acquisition and 
resettlement, and this experience is expected to facilitate resettlement implementation for the 
Project.  MOR  will  prepare  progress  reports  and  submit  them  to  ADB  each  quarter,  until 
resettlement  is  completed.  MOR  will  then  prepare  a  resettlement  completion  report  for 
submission to ADB. In addition, MOR will contract an independent monitor to carry out external 
monitoring and evaluation. The tasks include (i) conducting a baseline survey; (ii) reviewing and 
verifying the compensation payments, status of land acquisition, and compensation payments;

the completion of the resettlement activities; thereafter, annual evaluation investigations will be
